Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: The child has been promised a Nintendo, and the father should purchase it
Expectation2: Contribute to community well-being through paying taxes, following public health and safety guidance, and helping in emergencies
Situation2: Tax documents are organized a month before the deadline, and a free vaccine clinic runs this weekend at the community center.
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, my son’s hopeful eyes fixed on me as he reminded me, for the third time this week, about the Nintendo I’d promised him. He’d been saving his allowance, but the rest was up to me. I wanted to keep my word, to see his face light up, to be the father who provides not just the basics, but a little joy. But as I glanced at the stack of tax documents I’d organized, I remembered the community vaccine clinic this weekend. They needed volunteers, and I’d always believed in doing my part—helping out, making sure our neighborhood stayed safe and healthy. The Nintendo would take a chunk out of our budget, and volunteering would mean less time to work extra hours. I felt the weight of both roles pressing in: the expectation to give my son what he wanted, and the responsibility to support my community. My mind raced, torn between the promise I’d made at home and the duty I felt as a citizen.
